channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Man Claiming to Be American Tells CNN He’s Detained in North Korea
item.description: The North’s authorities brought the man, identified as Kim Dong-chul, 62, to a hotel in the capital to be interviewed by a CNN reporter, the network said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Revolt Network Foments New Brand of Jewish Terror in Israel
item.description: Israel’s domestic security agency sees a group of young extremists from settlement outposts as being behind a wave of violence against Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yisrael Ben-Shlomo at his sheep pen in the West Bank. He described Mordechai Meyer, 18, as “a good and wholesome kid,” but Israel’s domestic security agency says Mr. Meyer belongs to a Jewish terror network.

item.title: How Rolling Stone Magazine Handled a Get With Ramifications
item.description: After Rolling Stone magazine accepted Sean Penn’s pitch for an exclusive with the outlaw Joaquín Guzmán Loera, communications about the project became coded.
item.dc:creator: RAVI SOMAIYA
item.media:description: The actor Sean Penn, left, and the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera in a photo taken for interview authentication purposes.

item.title: Obama’s Guests at State of the Union Include Syrian Refugee and Mexican Immigrant
item.description: Also invited is Jim Obergefell, the lead plaintiff in the Supreme Court case legalizing gay marriage, and others who illustrate America as “inclusive and compassionate.”
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS FANDOS
item.media:credit: From left, Carlos Osorio/Associated Press; Staff Sgt. Jeffrey Smith, via U.S. Army; Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Refaai Hamo, a Syrian refugee, Oscar Vazquez, a Mexican immigrant, and Jim Obergefell, a petitioner in the same-sex marriage case last year, will be guests at the State of the Union address on Tuesday.

item.title: Suspect Shot by Paris Police Tied to German Migrant House
item.description: The German police said the man, who approached a Paris police station with fake explosives last week, had lived in a house for migrants in Germany.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: An anti-explosive robot approached the body of a suspect who was shot dead by police in Paris last week after he approached a police station with a meat cleaver and fake explosives.

item.title: El Chapo Faces Array of Drug Charges in United States
item.description: Joaquín Guzmán Loera has never appeared in an American court, though after his capture, Mexico indicated it might cooperate after years of requests by the United States.
item.dc:creator: ERIC LICHTBLAU

item.title: News Analysis: Theatrics Surrounding El Chapo’s Capture Distract From Mexico’s Real Woes
item.description: The revelation that Sean Penn interviewed the fugitive drug trafficker gave some Mexicans further justification for their abiding cynicism toward government.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: On the run, Joaquín Guzmán Loera hoped to make a movie, but his plan led to his capture, officials said.

item.title: An Uncertain New Chapter in Sinaloa, Home State of ‘El Chapo’
item.description: To many residents in Sinaloa, where Joaquín Guzmán Loera was captured, he was and remains El Señor (the Lord), a mythical figure who inspires as much respect as fear.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS and ALBERTO ARCE
item.media:description: Officers kept watch outside the house where the Mexican drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera, known as El Chapo, was captured in Los Mochis, Mexico on Friday.

item.title: Sean Penn’s Excursions Into Writing Often Mix Activism With Journalism
item.description: Mr. Penn’s nonfiction writing has often been about controversial subjects, as is his interview with the Mexican drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera.
item.dc:creator: DAVE ITZKOFF
item.media:description: In 2010 Sean Penn carried the belongings of a shelter camp resident who was preparing for relocation to a new camp in Haiti.

item.title: Hospital Aided by Doctors Without Borders Is Bombed in Yemen
item.description: At least four people were killed and the Shiara Hospital, in northern Yemen, near the border with Saudi Arabia, suffered severe damage.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: In Show of Alliance, American Forces Fly B-52 Bomber Over South Korea
item.description: The bomber was dispatched on Sunday to conduct training missions after North Korea’s fourth underground nuclear test.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: A United States Air Force B-52 bomber flew over Osan Air Base in South Korea on Sunday after North Korea’s fourth nuclear test.

item.title: Kate del Castillo, Actress Tied to El Chapo, Set Up Sean Penn Meeting
item.description: Ms. del Castillo, a Mexican television star, is believed to have brokered the meeting between the drug lord, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, and Mr. Penn last year.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Kate del Castillo on the red carpet at the premiere of “The 33” in Hollywood in November.

item.title: China’s Hunger for Commodities Wanes, and Pain Spreads Among Producers
item.description: For years, China gobbled up metals, crops and fuels for its rapidly expanding economy, and producers aggressively broadened operations to satisfy China’s appetite. Now, all has changed.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS
item.media:description: India continues to invest in mining despite a coal surplus.

item.title: Neglect May Do What ISIS Didn’t: Breach Iraqi Dam
item.description: The United States is urgently warning the Iraqi government to prepare its people for the dam’s failure, fearing up to 500,000 could be killed if repairs don’t come in time.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Kurdish fighters stood guard at Mosul Dam in Iraq in August after they and Iraqi forces retook the dam from the Islamic State.

item.title: Israeli Police Investigate B’Tselem Office Fire
item.description: No one was hurt in the fire at the offices of the Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories, which has been at the center of a political dispute.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Pope Benedict’s Brother Says He Was Unaware of Abuse
item.description: The Rev. Georg Ratzinger said in an interview that he had no knowledge that boys in the internationally known choir he once directed had been sexually abused.
item.category: Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Camp Phoenix Journal: From Under Kabul’s Bridges, Addicts Get Help at Old U.S. Base
item.description: Afghanistan is the world’s biggest opium producer, and there is evidence that the country’s drug problem is worse than government officials acknowledge.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and JAWAD SUKHANYAR
item.media:description: A doctor checked patients at Camp Phoenix last week. The camp, set up by the United States in 2003, is now the nation’s biggest rehab facility.

item.title: Catalonia’s New Leader Vows to Continue Secessionist Drive
item.description: Carles Puigdemont told the regional Parliament, “This isn’t a time for cowards, nor for rashness, nor for renunciations.”
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: Carles Puigdemont, the new leader of the regional government in Catalonia, Spain.

item.title: Starving Syrians in Madaya Are Denied Aid Amid Political Jockeying
item.description: As international powers intensify military and diplomatic activities in Syria, residents in besieged areas have gone without access to food and medicine.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD, HWAIDA SAAD and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Lebanese protesters at the border with Syria held a sign reading “We swear we are hungry” with images of starving children from Madaya, a town under siege in Syria.

item.title: Mexico Moves to Extradite Drug Kingpin Called El Chapo to the U.S.
item.description: Mexican officials said the process to extradite Joaquín Guzmán Loera could take months, and his lawyers are expected to fight it.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: A photo released on Friday by a Mexican website, Plaza de Armas, of Mr. Guzmán, who was recaptured in Los Mochis.
